name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SFChronicleFood: Unlike everyone else, you have very legit, TOTALLY OK reasons for attending a big French Laundry dinner party during a global pandemic https://t.co/3yAhMwbgJ5

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @hooleil: I'm standing against the cancellation of our fine politicians for daring to enjoy fine dining with a few close friends https://t.co/ZTr1mrPlt7

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @JanelleBitker: Chicken breasts grown in a lab are HAPPENING! SF's @eatjust has become the first in the world to clear regulatory hurdles to sell cultured meat https://t.co/PxAqt1J42n

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SFChronicleFood: Meat grown in a lab isn't some futuristic concept anymore. A San Francisco company just became the first in the world approved to sell it. https://t.co/6qotK9xGJQ

name: sfchronicle
text: Just a few days before Thanksgiving, Liccardo tweeted “Cases are spiking, in part because we’re letting our guard (and masks) down with family & friends. Let’s cancel the big gatherings this year and focus on keeping each other safe.” https://t.co/bCLZFM33XK

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @ronkroichick: One bit of news atop this story: Stanford men's team, now playing in Maui Invitational in North Carolina (only in 2020), plans to stay in N.C. to play four more non-conference games. That's in the wake of new Santa Clara County restrictions. 
https://t.co/ZRlHhmkN8W

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @SFC_Datebook: To drum up interest for a new #Batman comic strip in 1966, @SFChronicle gave away a poor imitation of the caped crusader’s signature ride. So who brought it home?

Read more here: 
https://t.co/biRXcyK48o

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @JanelleBitker: "Your bubbles are so airtight, they might as well be made of titanium."

Politicians contemplating a trip to the French Laundry might want to read this first. https://t.co/PmpRDZfzhI

name: sfchronicle
text:
A San Francisco company is set to be the first in the world to sell meat grown in a lab.

@JanelleBitker has the details here: https://t.co/Ppl49kBbMp

name: sfchronicle
text:
More than 270,000 U.S. residents now have lost their lives to the coronavirus. 

The nation passed the milestone on Tuesday as the pandemic continued raging across the country and the world, according to data from Johns Hopkins University. https://t.co/zs0PZQULeF

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @TonyBravoSF: Hey Bay Area parents, would still love to connect to talk to you about how you're dealing with Santa this year for your kids with Covid restrictions. DMs open!Hey Bay Area parents, would still love to connect to talk to you about how you're dealing with Santa this year for… https://t.co/ShIsRfqFui

name: sfchronicle
text:
"You on the other hand know the rules so well — you're kind of in charge of explaining them, after all — that you know specifically, to the letter, why your situation is an exception to those rules."  

Satire from @hooleil: 
https://t.co/h3qpMFsFjR

name: sfchronicle
text: #49ers’ biggest foe in December, writes @AnnKillion, will be their separation from loved ones. https://t.co/EEZK5I1dls https://t.co/AJWFKf2ggV

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @demianbulwa: Every day this month on https://t.co/dUv334n53p, we're going to be replaying our best storytelling from recent years.

First up: "150 Minutes of Hell" from 2018, @lizziejohnsonnn's harrowing story of death and survival in a tornado of fire https://t.co/eJRq5RSFpm

name: sfchronicle
text:
As Californians face increasingly restrictive orders to curb the swelling pandemic, public health experts say the targeted measures applied so far may not be enough, and another strict lockdown may be on the horizon.

Story by @ErinAllday & @MusicSF: https://t.co/Ok4ChC9JON

name: sfchronicle
text: The return of high school sports in California — which was expected next week with the first football practices of the coronavirus-altered season — has been pushed back to next month, and possibly later. https://t.co/T6SwNTjjcY

name: sfchronicle
sfchronicle
text:
San Francisco has pulled back on a plan to close hotels for the homeless this month, but the news has done little to curb the uncertainty that many residents still face in 2021.

Story by @TrishaThadani: https://t.co/ZML1l2Hyxm

name: sfchronicle
text:
California Supreme Court will rule on allowing 14- and 15-year old to be tried as adults.

Story by @BobEgelko: https://t.co/OM0pA4XPLr

name: sfchronicle
text: San Francisco Mayor London Breed joined a socialite's dinner at the French Laundry the night after Gavin Newsom -- and banned indoor dining in SF three days later. https://t.co/eDCJm9piWR

name: sfchronicle
text: The @49ers will decamp to the desert for much of December. https://t.co/dvSNsOhPuN

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SportingGreenSF: Rachel Luba of Monterey ( @AgentRachelLuba ) is one of the few women to work as a baseball agent, and this winter she has the most high-profile free agent client available, ace pitcher Trevor Bauer, writes @SusanSlusser  https://t.co/3RRL3KPGyU

name: sfchronicle
text: The @sfgiants announced they have hired J.P. Martinez, a onetime Minnesota Twins farmhand, as their new assistant pitching coach. https://t.co/REwyD4jdQo

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @demianbulwa: "The fraud case against San Francisco’s now-former Public Utilities Commission chief Harlan Kelly may have serious implications for another high-ranking city official: His wife, City Administrator Naomi Kelly."

Latest from @meganrcassidy  https://t.co/3td9gZ0FSR

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SFChronicleFood: The cultured chicken from San Francisco’s Eat Just is the first of its kind in the world to be approved for sale. https://t.co/GK0VK1sKmZ

name: sfchronicle
text:
RT @meganrcassidy: Federal prosecutors say City Administrator Naomi Kelly went on an overseas trip intended as a bribe for her husband, and suggested she misled the FBI when asked about it.  

The allegations have raised serious questions about Kelly's future with the city.
https://t.co/azJhPQuhTo

name: sfchronicle
text:
#Warriors’ positive coronavirus tests show how precarious this season will be.

Story by @Con_Chron: https://t.co/sDSs9Z1sKu

name: sfchronicle
text: Los Angeles County officials reported the highest number of new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations since the start of the pandemic on Tuesday, with 7,593 new cases and 2,316 hospitalizations. https://t.co/OyglRvMnGo

name: sfchronicle
text:
A federal grand jury indicted the captain of the Conception dive boat on 34 counts of seaman’s manslaughter, accusing him of not implementing adequate safety protocols before the boat caught fire last year.

Story by @Michaeldamianw: https://t.co/XYe2hHosQk

name: sfchronicle
text: Massachusetts is still seeing too many COVID-19 clusters that can be traced back to houses of worship, the state’s Republican governor, Charlie Baker, said at a Tuesday press conference. https://t.co/qZz3a8LWc0

name: sfchronicle
text:
- Stay as healthy as possible
- Get Curry acclimated to his new supporting cast
- Ratchet up the tempo
- Figure out the center rotation

@con_chron takes a look at the most pressing items on Warriors’ training-camp to-do list: https://t.co/32KpU2dNKJ

name: sfchronicle
text: The traditional tree lighting event outside of McLaren Lodge in Golden Gate Park will not take place this year due to the coronavirus pandemic, the San Francisco Recreation and Park Department announced on Tuesday. https://t.co/0KDI6P2PIh

name: sfchronicle
text: The Bay Area is not due to receive any wetting rains in the coming weeks, a dire forecast sparking renewed fears of fire as the region’s highest elevations remain worryingly dry. https://t.co/gvUHsfQjJv

name: sfchronicle
text:
“Our dangerous winter has arrived,” said Mayor London Breed. “We’re going to have to take more restrictive action, and it pains me to say that.” 

San Francisco is on the cusp of ordering further shutdowns >> https://t.co/GVesiwqjtk

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @Con_Chron: The Warriors' two positive coronavirus tests showed just how precarious this season could be: https://t.co/eSoHadRm3T

text:

name: sfchronicle
text: In November, the month-over-month decline in S.F. rent was 3.4% with an average price of $2,054 for a one-bedroom apartment, and $2,377 for a two-bedroom unit, according to the December report from @ApartmentList. https://t.co/hlrmTB5tu9

name: sfchronicle
text:
